document.docAuthor: Peng, Lingfei, Xiang, Jiawei & Liu, Qifei
document.docTitle: Zaischnopsis candetibia Peng & Xiang & Liu 2018, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Three new species of Zaischnopsis Ashmead (Hymenoptera: Chalcidoidea: Eupelmidae) from Southern China, with redescription of Zaischnopsis tubatius (Walker)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Three new species of Zaischnopsis Ashmead (Hymenoptera: Chalcidoidea: Eupelmidae) from Southern China, with redescription of Zaischnopsis tubatius (Walker)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material.
Holotype ♀ ( BMNH ): Tien Fong Mts , Hainan Prov.,
17.V.1983
, Bouček ( NHMUK010353630 )
.
Paratype : Danxian , Hainan Prov.,
11.V.1983
, Bouček ( NHMUK010353624 ) ( 1♀ BMNH )
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1‒11.
Zaischnopsis candetibia
. 1, body, dorsal; 2, propodeum, dorsal (arrow points to broadly V-shaped anterior margin of propodeum); 3, antenna; 4, head, lateral; 5, head, frontal; 6, head, dorsal; 7, mesosoma, dorsal; 8, hind leg, lateral; 9, tibia and tarsi of midleg; 10, fore wing; 11, gaster, dorsal.

subSubSection.paragraph: Gaster longer than mesosoma ( Fig. 1 ), elongate-lanceolate ( Fig. 11 ); Gt 1 –Gt 3 deeply V-like emarginate, Gt 4 and Gt 5 slightly emarginate, Gt 6 convex, syntergum tapered to sharp apex ( Fig. 40 ); ovipositor sheath exserted for short distance, as long as 4/5 of basal metatarsomere.
Variation. The female paratype is 4.7 mm in length; scrobal depression separated from anterior ocellus by distance about 0.9× diameter of anterior ocellus.

Remarks. Females of this new species have a similar fore wing colour pattern ( Fig. 10 ) as those of
Z. tubatius
( Fig. 34 ),
Z. keralensis
( Fig. 48 ) and
Z. mampadicus
( Fig. 52 ), but differ by the dorsal margin of the metatibia being white basally ( Fig. 8 ). Further, the tibial spur of
Z. keralensis
is yellow or pale yellow, Gt 3 is slightly emarginate and Gt 4 is evenly convex, whereas
Z. candetibia
has the mesotibial spur very dark brown to black, Gt 3 is deeply emarginate, and Gt 4 is slightly emarginate; the middle of the propodeum of
Z. tubatius
is very narrow ( Figs 36 , 47 ), whereas the middle of propodeum of
Z. candetibia
is broader ( Figs 2 , 44 ). The gaster of
Z. mampadicus
was described as about 1.8× longer than the mesosoma, whereas the gaster of
Z. candetibia
is only about 1.4× longer than the mesosoma.
Etymology. The species name is a combination of the Latin words “ candeo ” which means shining white, and “ tibia ”, in reference to the metatibia having a white margin basally.
